data.title: The Bancorp targets $7 EPS run rate by Q4 2026 amid fintech expansion and platform restructuring
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: The Bancorp, Inc. (TBBK) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Damian Kozlowski, CEO, reported that "in the third quarter, The Bancorp earned $1.18 earnings per share on revenue growth of 7%, excluding consumer fintech loan credit enhancement income and expense growth of 6%." EPS grew 13% year-over-year, while fintech GDV continued to grow above trend at 16%. He highlighted revenue growth in the quarter, including both fee and related interest income, as 23%.
  • Kozlowski outlined progress in three main fintech initiatives: credit sponsorship balances ended at 785, up 15% from the second quarter and 180% year-over-year; the embedded finance platform is set for launch next year; and the Cash App program is on track with revenue expected in the first quarter of 2026. He stated, "All 3 initiatives should have an increasingly positive effect on our financials as we move forward through '26 and into 2027."
  • The company reduced criticized REBL assets from $216 million to $185 million, a 14% quarter-over-quarter decline, and expects more progress in the fourth quarter.
  • Under Project 7, Kozlowski announced a restructuring of the institutional banking business in Q4 2025, reducing headcount by 30 and decreasing run rate expenses by approximately $8 million, with a $1.3 million restructuring charge expected in Q4.
  • Kozlowski disclosed that guidance for 2025 is being lowered to $5.10 per share, primarily due to lower projected balances in traditional lending and increased credit provision for leasing. Preliminary guidance for 2027 is introduced at $8.25 earnings per share.
  • Martin Egan, Interim CFO, stated, "Excluding consumer fintech loan credit enhancement income, noninterest income for the third quarter of 2025 was $40.6 million, which was 27% higher than the third quarter of 2024. Total fintech fees accounted for most of that increase."
  • Egan also reported a $2.3 million settlement included in other income and provision for credit losses on nonconsumer fintech loans of $5.8 million for the quarter, with $4.8 million related to the leasing portfolio.

Outlook

  • Kozlowski reported that "we are lowering guidance to $5.10-ish a share for '25, primarily due to lower projected balances on our traditional lending businesses and an increased credit provision for leasing due to losses on the disposition of previously identified credits in trucking."
  • The company is not providing specific guidance for 2026 other than targeting a minimum $7 earnings per share run rate by the end of 2026.
  • Preliminary guidance for 2027 is set at $8.25 earnings per share.
  • Kozlowski said, "EPS gains are subject to uncertainty, particularly as it relates to the development implementation time lines in fintech and our stock price for buybacks."

Financial Results

  • Fintech fees for the quarter increased, with prepaid, debit card, ACH and other payment fees reaching $30.6 million, a 10% increase year-over-year, and consumer credit fintech fees rising $2.9 million to $4.5 million.
  • Provision for credit losses on nonconsumer fintech loans totaled $5.8 million, with $4.8 million related to leasing. Net charge-offs in leasing were $2.8 million, primarily from the trucking industry.
  • Average fintech solutions deposits grew 10% to $7.3 billion from $6.6 billion a year ago.
  • Noninterest expense for the quarter was $56.4 million, up 6% from the prior year, including a 10% increase in salaries and benefits.

Q&A

  • Timothy Switzer, KBW, asked for an update on the Cash App program timeline. Kozlowski replied, "it's on track and revenue is expected in Q1. We're not sure exactly the ramp-up schedule because it's really dependent on time lines at Block at Cash App."
  • Switzer inquired about the $27 million REBL loan sale. Kozlowski responded, "that $27 million is expected to close in the next 5 days."
  • Switzer questioned the activity in closing new loan sales. Kozlowski noted, "we've just been working with the borrowers, some in deferrals, right? ... The market has improved generally for these assets."
  • Switzer asked about lower deposits. Kozlowski explained, "There's a big seasonality part of it. ... We have plenty of deposits. The question is how do we manage it through the cycle so that we don't have these big ups and downs."
  • Joseph Yanchunis, Raymond James, sought details on share repurchases and guidance. Kozlowski said guidance includes buybacks and, "At that point, it will be $300-plus million of net income."
  • Yanchunis also asked about fintech fees' sequential decline. Kozlowski replied, "there's a lot of volatility. There's incentive fees. There's a whole bunch of things in there, and there's seasonality in there, too... but then it starts ramping up again."
  • Arif Gangat asked about REBL loan delinquency. Egan responded, "Some of that will be resolved in that $102 million that's under contract."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed for clarity on new program timelines, loan sales, deposit management, and share repurchase assumptions, showing a neutral to slightly cautious tone.
  • Management maintained confidence in fintech initiatives and guidance, though acknowledged uncertainties, as Kozlowski stated, "EPS gains are subject to uncertainty." During Q&A, explanations were more detailed, indicating thoroughness but also caution given the moving parts.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's tone shifted from more assertive to slightly more measured, reflecting the lower guidance and ongoing restructuring.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance was lowered from $5.25 to $5.10 per share for 2025, with preliminary 2027 guidance newly introduced at $8.25 per share.
  • The three main fintech initiatives remain a focal point, but the platform restructuring and AI investment have become more prominent.
  • Analysts continued to focus on loan performance, fintech fee volatility, and deposit dynamics, similar to the previous quarter.
  • Management's confidence remains but is tempered by increased references to uncertainty and operational adjustments, versus a more upbeat tone in Q2.

Risks and Concerns

  • Increased provision for credit losses in leasing, particularly from trucking sector exposures.
  • Lower projected balances in traditional lending.
  • Ongoing volatility in fintech fee income and deposit balances.
  • Uncertainty around fintech implementation timelines and the impact of share buybacks is acknowledged by management.

Final Takeaway

The Bancorp is navigating a transition period, with management emphasizing progress in fintech initiatives, platform efficiency, and restructuring efforts. While guidance for 2025 has been adjusted downward, leadership remains focused on achieving a $7 earnings per share run rate by the end of 2026 and sees further growth into 2027, driven by new product launches, AI-enabled efficiencies, and continued capital return through share buybacks.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Silvercrest outlines path to record discretionary AUM through ongoing global investments
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Silvercrest Asset Management Group Inc. (SAMG) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Richard Hough, CEO, President & Chairman, reported that discretionary assets under management (AUM) increased $687 million during the third quarter, attributing the growth primarily to beneficial equity markets. New client account flows were highlighted, with $46.4 million added in organic new client accounts during the quarter and $564 million year-to-date through Q3. Hough stated, “Discretionary AUM now stands at $24.3 billion, which is a 3% sequential quarterly increase and an increase of 8% year-over-year.” He further noted, “Total AUM at the end of the third quarter did hit a new high for the firm at $37.6 billion.”

  • Hough emphasized, “Silvercrest has embarked on significant strategic investments to promote growth opportunities,” with a focus on intellectual capital and headcount, which has led to substantially lower earnings and adjusted EBITDA in the near-term.

  • He announced an ongoing $25 million buyback program, stating, “As of the end of the third quarter of 2025, we have repurchased approximately $16 million worth of shares.” He also referenced a dividend of $0.21 per share set to be paid in December and plans to distribute equity incentives to professionals in the near future.

  • CFO Scott Gerard reported, “Revenue for the quarter was $31.3 million and reported consolidated net income for the quarter was $1.1 million.” Gerard added, “Expenses for the quarter increased year-over-year by $4 million or 15.4%, primarily driven by increased compensation and benefits expense and general and administrative expenses.”

Outlook

  • Hough indicated that, “Assuming supportive markets and continued business development, we hope discretionary AUM will exceed all-time highs in the coming quarters.” He also described a plan to adjust nondiscretionary AUM reporting in 2026 to provide clearer business metrics.

  • Management expects the compensation ratio to remain elevated for the foreseeable future due to ongoing investments in personnel and global marketing.

  • The firm’s pipeline remains “robust, in particular with regards to our new global value equity strategy.” Hough highlighted, “We could see even some reasonable allocations in the fourth quarter or first quarter coming up here… which would obviously cover about 6 months.”

Financial Results

  • Gerard reported, “Revenue for the quarter increased $0.9 million or 2.9% year-over-year.” Compensation and benefits expense rose $3.1 million or 16.8% year-over-year, influenced by both merit-based increases and new hires, and an increase in the accrual for bonuses.

  • General and administrative expenses climbed $0.9 million or approximately 11.9% year-over-year, attributed to professional fees, occupancy, and recruiting costs.

  • Reported net income attributable to Class A shareholders for the quarter was $0.6 million or $0.07 per basic and diluted Class A share. Adjusted EBITDA was $4.5 million or 14.5% of revenue for the quarter. Adjusted net income was $2.4 million or $0.19 per adjusted basic and diluted earnings per share.

  • As of September 30, total assets stood at $157.6 million, with cash and cash equivalents at $36.1 million. No borrowings were reported, and total Class A stockholders’ equity was $58.9 million. The company repurchased $4.6 million worth of Class A shares during the quarter.

Q&A

  • Christopher Marinac, Janney Montgomery Scott: “Do we think about this as maybe an 18-, 24-month time frame? Or is it any way to kind of give visibility on that?” Hough responded that the bulk of investments have been recent and that, “you’re looking at a longer time horizon of 18 to 24 months,” but also expects shorter-term flows in the next 6 to 12 months from the global value equity strategy.

  • Marinac: “Are any of those [professional fees] temporary? Or will you have new professional fees to kind of cover in future periods?” Gerard replied, “Some of them are temporary, especially related to some of our global initiatives.”

  • Marinac: “Does the EBITDA margin get recast because it’s now going to be a different company with a different broader focus?” Hough answered, “You look out further and it gets back to where it was barring any other new investments.”

  • Sandy Mehta, Evaluate Research: “Can you just give us a little bit more color on what you’re seeing from a marketing perspective, the pipeline and what clients are saying or consultants are saying, what do you see out there on Global?” Hough described the pipeline as “very large” in international and global areas and noted, “our new centralized institutional marketing team and process has been highly engaged both with very significant sovereign pools of capital.”

  • Mehta: “Is most of the hiring done at this point of the senior people that you were hiring? Is that pace of incremental hires? Is that going to slow down?” Hough responded that most hiring for new equity strategy and institutional team is complete but further hires are expected for Europe, Asia, and domestically.

  • Mehta: “Where are you in terms of OCIO assets, currently?” Hough reported, “OCIO is almost $2.2 billion and has a very strong pipeline.”

  • Mehta: “Do you disclose what price you bought the stock?” Hough stated, “We don’t disclose it. I will say that it has been, from our thinking, a very, very favorable price.”

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts’ tone was generally neutral to slightly positive, focusing on the timing of returns from investments, the sustainability of professional fees, and the scale of hiring. Follow-up questions probed operating leverage and the trajectory of margins but did not express skepticism or overt concern.

  • Management maintained a confident tone, emphasizing the potential payoff from recent investments: “The potential is very large. And I’m quite confident that it is going to pay off and that we will be able to report meaningful progress soon.” Hough acknowledged the longer time horizon but was optimistic about near-term flows and future profitability.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, the current call reflected continued confidence in strategic initiatives, with management reiterating optimism about organic growth while acknowledging ongoing expense pressures and a longer investment payback period.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance continues to anticipate future record AUM levels, with management expecting discretionary AUM to exceed all-time highs in coming quarters, similar to the positive outlook last quarter.

  • Strategic focus remains on organic growth through international expansion, global value equity strategies, and headcount investments. The firm has moved from announcing new strategic hires to discussing the absorption and expected payoff of those investments.

  • Analysts’ questions shifted slightly from pipeline measurement and the pace of buybacks (Q2) to the timing of investment returns, margin recovery, and hiring trajectory (Q3), reflecting growing interest in when strategic investments will convert to earnings growth.

  • Key metrics reflect moderate sequential growth in AUM and revenue, but a noticeable decline in net income and EBITDA margin due to higher compensation and G&A expenses.

  • Management’s confidence level is steady, with ongoing emphasis on the size and quality of the pipeline and the robustness of international initiatives.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management highlighted elevated compensation and G&A expenses as ongoing challenges, tied to strategic hires and global expansion.

  • Analysts inquired about the possibility of continued high professional fees and whether the pace of hiring would slow, indicating concern about expense management relative to revenue realization.

  • Hough acknowledged that the timeline for investment returns is variable, with most hiring complete for current initiatives but further additions expected internationally and domestically.

Final Takeaway

Silvercrest Asset Management Group continues to invest heavily in its global and institutional capabilities, with discretionary AUM and total AUM both reaching new highs. Management is confident that recent investments in talent and international expansion will result in accelerated organic growth over the next 18 to 24 months, with a robust pipeline supporting future revenue. Expense pressures are expected to remain elevated in the near term, but the firm anticipates a return to higher margins as new business flows materialize. Investors should watch for updates on realized flows from global strategies and continued progress in international markets as key drivers for future earnings and AUM growth.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Brighthouse Financial surges 20% on report Aquarian nears $4B deal
data.description:
• Brighthouse Financial (BHF) jumped 20% after a report that Aquarian Holdings was in advanced talks to acquire the US life insurer.
  • Mubadala Capital-backed Aquarian Holding is expected to pay as much as $70 a share for Brighthouse, according to a Financial Times report  on Thursday. A deal could be announced as soon as this weekend.
  • Although talks have reached an advanced stage, no deal has yet been agreed to and talks could still fall apart, according to the report.
  • Brighthouse, Aquarian and Mubadala Capital declined to comment to the FT.

data.title: Roku stock turns positive and climbs +15% after Q3 profit beat
data.description:
Roku (ROKU) on Thursday reported a profit beat for the third quarter and provided a forecast that mostly matched Wall Street's expectations.

Shares fell more than 15% in immediate reaction to the report before paring losses. ROKU stock is up 15.6% in Friday's open market trading.

For the fourth quarter, Roku expects revenue to be $1.35B, ahead of the Bloomberg consensus estimate of $1.32B; gross profit of $575M, above the $571.9M estimate; and adjusted EBITDA of $395M vs. the consensus estimate of $376.2M.

The company, which makes streaming devices and owns a complimentary, ad-supported channel, said users streamed 36.5B hours in Q3, up 15% from last year, but below the estimate of 37.5B hours. 

Net income for the three months ended September 30 was $28.8M, compared with a loss of $9M for the same period last year.

On a per-share basis, the company earned 16 cents, beating the average analyst expectation of 8 cents a share.

Revenue rose 14% to $1.21B and was in line with the consensus estimate.

data.title: Black Diamond Group Limited raises dividend by 28.6% to CAD 0.045
data.description:
• Black Diamond Group Limited (BDI:CA) declares CAD 0.045/share quarterly dividend, 28.6% increase from prior dividend of CAD 0.035.
  • Payable Jan. 15; for shareholders of record Dec. 31; ex-div Dec. 31.
  • See BDI:CA Dividend Scorecard, Yield Chart, & Dividend Growth.

data.title: Wall Street rallies higher on Amazon and Apple earnings
data.description:
Wall Street moved higher on Friday with the major indexes advancing as upbeat earnings from big tech companies fueled investor optimism.

Rising the most on the session was the tech focused Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) which was last up 0.9%. At the same time, the benchmark S&P 500 (SP500) was in the green by 0.4%, and the blue-chip Dow (DJI) climbed up 0.1%.

From a sector point of view, five of the 11 S&P segments advanced with Consumer Discretionary leading the way. At the other end of the spectrum, the Materials space has suffered the most on the session so far.

U.S. Treasury yields ticked lower with the longer-end U.S. 10-year Treasury yield (US10Y) falling 1 basis point to 4.08% and the shorter-end U.S. 2-year Treasury yield (US2Y) moved down by 1 basis point to 3.60%.

"Indeed, just as the tech mood had soured yesterday, this morning that has mostly turned around following results from Apple and Amazon after the closing bell," Deutsche Bank's Jim Reid said.

Amazon (AMZN) soared 11.3% after it topped Q3 estimates with better-than-expected net sales, profits, and subscription revenues, and more importantly. It also delivered a beat on the company’s AWS, all of which offset compressed margins.

Apple (AAPL) traded near even after the tech giant reported fiscal fourth-quarter results that topped estimates.

On political news, the U.S. States reportedly cancelled a planned Budapest summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin following Russia's firm stance on hardline demands regarding Ukraine.

data.title: JPMorgan takes equity stake in TXSE as part of second capital raise
data.description:
JPMorgan Chase (JPM) made an equity investment in Texas Stock Exchange Group ("TXSE") as part of the TXSE's second-round capital raise ahead of its planned launch in Q1 2026, the company said on Friday.

As part of JPMorgan's (JPM) investment, the bank will join TXSE Group's board of directors as an observer. Combined with previous fundraising, TXSE has raised more than $250M. 

Bloomberg News reported that the TXSE raised ~$90M from a group of investors in the latest capital raise. In September 2024, the company said it had raised $135M. The exchange had raised $120M in early 2024, with BlackRock (BLK) and Citadel Securities participating.

"Our strong capital position validates our mission to bring increased competition to the U.S. capital markets," said James H Lee, founder and CEO of TXSE Group. "The Texas Stock Exchange's focus on alignment and transparency for issuers will alter the trajectory of our public markets and help establish Texas as a new global leader in capital markets."

Charles Schwab (SCHW) is another prominent investor in the exchange. In total, 82 financial institutions and business leaders have invested in TXSE Group.

data.title: WisdomTree declares $0.03 dividend
data.description:
• WisdomTree (WT) declares $0.03/share quarterly dividend, in line with previous.
  • Forward yield 1.0%
  • Payable Nov. 26; for shareholders of record Nov. 12; ex-div Nov. 12.
  • See WT Dividend Scorecard, Yield Chart, & Dividend Growth.

data.title: Tego Cyber rebrands to VigilAigent Corp
data.description:
• Tego Cyber (TGCB) has officially changed its name to VigilAigent Corp, effective immediately.
  • The rebranding follows the launch of the VigilAigent Managed Security Services platform earlier this year.
  • The new identity reflects the company’s evolution into an Agentic AI-powered cybersecurity organization.
  • The VigilAigent platform combines Virtual Aigents (AI operatives) and Special Aigents (human SOC experts) for adaptive, autonomous defense.
  • The company will introduce a new ticker symbol.

data.title: Rithm Property Trust signals potential liquidation or recapitalization amid $5.30 book value and $2.40 stock price gap
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Rithm Property Trust Inc. (RPT) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Michael Nierenberg opened by stating, "when we took over this company last June, we stabilized the company, which at that time, I think was losing in and around $10 million a quarter. Today, the company essentially is flat when you take into account earnings and we're still paying a $0.06 dividend." He emphasized the liquidation of residential assets and the addition of commercial real estate floaters, describing these as "higher yielding top part of the capital stack with some reasonable yield."
  • Nierenberg highlighted options for the company: "we can recap the vehicle with an offering of equity associated with a pool of assets... we could explore some kind of liquidation of the company... Or three is, stay the course."
  • He stated, "with book value at $5.30 and the stock trading at $2.40-odd, clearly, there's a huge value play for equity investors in this."
  • The CEO detailed progress on developing a direct lending business, referencing partnerships with Genesis and the company's growth in construction loans: "we grew a company that was doing $1.7 billion in production. Today, we're going to -- this year, we'll probably do north of $5 billion."
  • Nierenberg reiterated, "we're not going to leave this thing outstanding for the sake of leaving a company outstanding. We need to either figure out a way to grow it or at some point, we'll likely think about an auction process for the company and realize what I think is going to be true book value."
  • He noted the company has "in and around $100 million of cash. The company has about $300 million in total equity. And the pipelines look great. The portfolio is about $308 million today."
  • CFO Nick Santoro was not directly quoted in the transcript section provided.

Outlook

  • Management discussed three possible paths: recapitalization, liquidation, or continued operations with a focus on growth, but stated, "we're not going to just stay the course and leave something outstanding for the sake of leaving something outstanding."
  • The CEO expressed optimism for the direct lending business and future deals, but stressed the need for execution: "we got to -- quite frankly, we have to execute on that plan."
  • On the Paramount acquisition, Nierenberg said, "one of the questions we got on yesterday's call, is it something that we consider adding some Paramount to the -- adding to the Rithm Property Trust and the answer, what I said was yes."
  • There was no explicit financial guidance or updated earnings targets provided for future quarters in the transcript.

Financial Results

  • Nierenberg described results as "effectively, the company was flat quarter-over-quarter, still maintained a $0.06 dividend. Cash and cash equivalents on balance sheet at the end of the quarter, $81 million and total equity is $292 million."
  • The company originated a $21 million loan on a grocery-anchored retail center outside Seattle, with an expected yield in the "mid-teens."
  • No other explicit financial figures, EPS, or revenue data were stated for the quarter.

Q&A

  • William Catherwood, BTIG, LLC: Asked about the current pool of loans in closing and the company's direction. Nierenberg responded, "there's a couple of things here. One is I brought up the Paramount deal. That's a big deal. I mean there's $6.60 on 13 million square feet... We have passed on what I would say, more of and some of this is, as you think about the mayoral election here... we're not going to do rent-stabilized loans in New York City right now."
  • Catherwood: Asked about the Paramount transaction and RPT's potential position. Nierenberg clarified, "they had some legacy funds. I would assume for purposes of this discussion, there's nothing to do with Rithm Property Trust and those funds. It would likely be a position that would be pari passu alongside Rithm, the parent."
  • Catherwood: Asked about discount to book value and credit risks across the sector. Nierenberg said, "a lot of the legacy commercial real estate REITs were still saddled with... underwater loans that need to get worked out. We do not have any of those here at our firm."
  • Craig Kucera, Lucid Capital Markets: Asked about economics of Paramount for RPT. Nierenberg said, "the Paramount deal is more equity based... a $50 million equity check gives you about a 2x MOIC on that $50 million and a 20-plus percent return based on our assumptions."
  • Kucera: Inquired about Rithm Capital deploying capital into RPT. Nierenberg responded, "I think to keep it clean, we'd prefer to do something that's not like that, but I don't know yet just to where we ultimately go."
  • Kucera: Asked about new third-party partners for RPC. Nierenberg said, "this deal has opened up conversations that truly we wouldn't have had 6 months ago."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts adopted a probing and skeptical tone, frequently focusing on the discount to book value, capital deployment plans, and potential for new transactions. Their questions often pressed for specifics on execution and risk, particularly regarding the Paramount deal and sector-wide credit concerns.
  • Management maintained an optimistic but pragmatic tone, emphasizing clean balance sheets and strategic optionality. In prepared remarks, Nierenberg was direct about possible strategic shifts. In Q&A, he showed confidence but occasionally hedged, saying, "I think to keep it clean, we'd prefer to do something that's not like that, but I don't know yet just to where we ultimately go."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone was more focused on strategic alternatives, while analysts were more pointed regarding risks and value realization.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter introduced more explicit discussion of company-altering moves, including liquidation or recapitalization, compared to the previous quarter’s emphasis on pipeline growth and capital deployment.
  • The previous quarter highlighted a robust pipeline and intent to avoid equity dilution, while the current call focused more on strategic options in light of persistent stock price discounts and capital constraints.
  • Analyst questions in the current quarter sharpened focus on execution risks, sector-wide credit concerns, and the mispricing of equity, reflecting increased market skepticism.
  • Management’s confidence in the direct lending platform and opportunistic nature of the portfolio was a recurring theme, but this quarter added a sense of urgency regarding potential major transactions.

Risks and Concerns

  • Nierenberg identified sector-wide risks, stating, "a lot of the legacy commercial real estate REITs were still saddled with... underwater loans that need to get worked out. We do not have any of those here."
  • He emphasized the company’s clean balance sheet and lack of legacy issues but acknowledged, "the thing is you need capital to grow. And with the stock trading at whatever, 50-odd percent of book, it's very difficult."
  • Analysts raised concerns about persistent equity mispricing, capital deployment effectiveness, and execution risks tied to potential major transactions like Paramount.

Final Takeaway

Rithm Property Trust management underscored the company’s clean balance sheet, ongoing dividend, and opportunistic strategy, while openly considering significant moves such as recapitalization or liquidation in response to the persistent gap between book value and share price. The call highlighted a focus on growth through direct lending and select asset acquisitions, with management stressing that all options remain under review to maximize shareholder value and address capital constraints.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript
